1.name: What is a Balance Sheet
1.textBoxContent1: The balance sheet shows what a company owns at a specific point in time. Different items like working capital, debt, stock and PPE show up as assets, liabilities, or equity and the key is that assets - liabilities = equity, if it doesn’t then your balance sheet doesn’t balance.

quiz.question: How do we check if the Balance Sheet Balances?

2.name: What is Working Capital
2.textBoxContent1: In this lesson you will be learning about working capital, one of the most important pieces of the balance sheet and 3 statement model as a whole. Working capital represents the money a company has available to run its day-to-day operations, like paying suppliers, covering payroll, and managing inventory. It tells you whether a business can meet its short-term obligations using its short-term resources. Some working capital items are assets like accounts receivable, and some are liabilities, like accounts payable.

quiz.question: What does Working Capital Represent?
options: The dbt obligation of the company
The money a company has to run its day to day operations
The total stock owned by the company
quiz.correctAnswer: The money a company has to run its day to day operations

3.name: Accounts Receivable
3.textBoxContent1: Accounts receivable is the money a company is owed by customers for goods or services it has delivered but hasn’t yet been paid for. When you buy something from a company with a credit card, you put Accounts Receivable on their balance sheet.

quiz.question: Which of these would be considered Accounts Receivables?
options: A loan the company takes out
A purchase a customer made on credit to the company
A purchase the company made on credit
quiz.correctAnswer: A purchase a customer made on credit to the company

4.name: Forecasting Accounts Receivable
4.textBoxContent1: To forecast Accounts Receivable, we use DSO, or days sales outstanding. Days sales outstanding represents the average amount of time between a sale on credit and the payment of that sale. To find DSO we can divide our most recent Accounts Receivables by our most recent Revenue and then multiply it by 365
4.hint: Use the formula: = E1 * (1 + $B$13) in the first cell and drag it to the other three

quiz.question: Find Days Sales Outstanding

5.name: Accounts Receivable
5.textBoxContent1: Now that we have found our historical DSO, we can use it to forecast Accounts Receivable. Multiply DSO by revenue for the year being forecasted and divide by 365 to get forecasted Accounts Receivable

quiz.question: Use DSO to Forecast Accounts Receivables

6.name: Inventory
6.textBoxContent1: Inventory is the items a company has ready to sell but hasn’t sold yet. It is counted as an asset.

quiz.question: Which of these would be considered Inventory

7.name: Forecasting Inventory
7.textBoxContent1: We use Days Inventory Outstanding to forecast Inventory. Days Inventory Outstanding can be found by dividing our most recent inventory by our most recent COGS and multiplying by 365
7.hint: use this formula and drag it to the 3 cells =F1*$B$14

quiz.question: Find DIO?

8.name: Forecast Inventory
8.textBoxContent1: Now that you have found Days Inventory Outstanding, we can forecast Inventory
8.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Enter Gross Profit for the highlighted cells

9.name: Other Current Assets
9.textBoxContent1: Other current assets represent the junk pile of working capital assets. Less relevant or smaller items like Pre Paid expenses, interest receivable, insurance recoverables, or advances to suppliers are included in other current assets to simplify the accounting process.
9.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Would Accounts Receivable be included in Other Current Assets?

10.name: Forecasting Other Current Assets
10.textBoxContent1: We forecast other current assets as a % of revenue most of the time. We can’t use days outstanding here because we have many different items lumped into one group.
10.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Find Other Current Assets / Revenue

11.name: Forecast Other Current Assets
11.textBoxContent1: Now that we have found Other Current Assets as a % of revenue, we can simply multiply that percentage by revenue for each year we would like to forecast.
11.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Enter Gross Profit for the highlighted cells

12.name: Operating Current Assets
12.textBoxContent1: Operating current assets are the working capital assets a company owns.
12.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Calculate Operating Current Assets

13.name: Calculating Operating Current Assets
13.textBoxContent1: To calculate Operating Current Assets, simply add up all working capital assets. In this model, that would be Accounts Receivables, Inventory, and Other Current Assets.
13.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Enter Gross Profit for the highlighted cells

14.name: Accounts Payable
14.textBoxContent1: Accounts Payable is the first Working Capital Liability we will cover. It represents the purchases that the company has made but not yet paid for. Think of it as the reverse of Accounts Receivables. If one company purchases something on credit, the purchasing company gains accounts payable on their balance sheet and the selling company gains accounts receivable on their balance sheet until the purchasing company pays.

quiz.question: What happens to the purchasing companies balance sheet when it pays its accounts payable?
options: Cash Decreases and Net Working Capital Decreases
Accounts Payables Decreaes and cash decreases
Cash increases and Accounts Receivable increases
quiz.correctAnswer: Accounts Payables Decreaes and cash decreases

15.name: Forecasting Accounts Payable
15.textBoxContent1: The best way to forecast Accounts Payable is using Days Payable Outstanding. We find Days Payable Outstanding by Dividing the most recent Accounts Payable by the most recent COGS and multiplying it by 365

quiz.question: Find Days Payable Outstanding
options: Freight charges for shipping raw materials
Cost of raw materials used in production

16.name: Forecast Accounts Payable
16.textBoxContent1: Using Days Payable outstanding, we can forecast Accounts Payable.

quiz.question: Forecast Accounts Payables
options: Freight charges for shipping raw materials
Cost of raw materials used in production

17.name: Other Current Liabilities
17.textBoxContent1: Other current liabilities is the miscellaneous bucket on the liabilities side of the balance sheet, similar to other current assets. It captures short-term obligations that don’t warrant individual line items due to immateriality or irregularity. Common examples include accrued expenses, deferred revenues, taxes payable, dividends payable, and wages payable.

quiz.question: Which of these would be in Other Current Liabilities

18.name: Forecasting Other Current Liabilities
18.textBoxContent1: We forecast Other Current Liabilities as a % of revenue most of the time.

quiz.question: Find Other Current Liabilities / Revenue
options: Beakers to study new lemonade flavors
Paying your friend to test new flavors

19.name: Forecast Other Current Liabilities
19.textBoxContent1: Using OCL as a % of revenue, we can forecast it by multiplying it by revenue for the desired year.

quiz.question: Calculate Other Current Liabilities
options: Beakers to study new lemonade flavors
Paying your friend to test new flavors

20.name: Operating Current Liabilities
20.textBoxContent1: Operating Current Liabilities represents the total of Working Capital Liabilities.
20.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: How would an increase in Accounts Receivable change Operating Current Liabilities

21.name: Forecasting Operating Current Liabilities
21.textBoxContent1: To calculate Operating Current Liabilities, add up Accounts Payable and Other Current Liabilities
21.hint: use the formula =F1 - F2 and drag to fill all cells

quiz.question: Enter Gross Profit for the highlighted cells

22.name: Net Working Capital
22.textBoxContent1: Now that we have all of our working capital assets and liabilities, we can find Net Working Capital. Net Working Capital is the difference between operating current assets and operating current liabilities. It represents the amount of short-term liquidity a company has to run its operations. A positive NWC means the company can cover its short-term obligations with its short-term assets. A negative NWC could signal liquidity risk or highly efficient working capital management, depending on the business model.

quiz.question: What does Net Working Capital tell us?
options: The companies ability to pay short term expenses
quiz.correctAnswer: The companies ability to pay short term expenses

23.name: Forecasting Net Working Capital
23.textBoxContent1: Net working capital is Operating Current Assets - Operating Current Liabilities

quiz.question: Find NWC
options: as a % of Revenue based on historical data
By subtracting Operational Expenses from Gross Profit
By forecasting as a % of Gross Profit
quiz.correctAnswer: as a % of Revenue based on historical data
